data.title: MY EXPERIENCE OF OLD CALABAR
data.meta_description: My tour to old Calabar was an unforgettable experience in the city. This tour was led by Mr. Martins, he was our amiable tour guide. The journey started from the Unical main gate down to Mary Slessor Avenue. There I saw the first major roundabout in Calabar, A statue of mary Slessor holding a set…
data.text:
My tour to old Calabar

was an unforgettable experience in the city. This tour was led by Mr. Martins, he was our amiable tour guide. The journey started from the Unical main gate down to Mary Slessor Avenue.

There I saw the first major roundabout in Calabar, A statue of mary Slessor holding a set of twins

just around it, by the left Is the Botanical Garden

made up of wildlife and well labeled tress including Pam trees for site viewing. It is the first of its kind in Nigeria and was established in (1896). This Garden was a good source of revenue to the government. According to Mr. Martins, “The garden was later renamed as the Calabar Zoo but due to the poor management and over drainage of revenue, they did away with the zoo and changed it to a conservation center”

The next facility we later visited was the cultural Center.

Most of the Calabar event are usually hosted there, followed by the famous Etim Edem Park; where we board vehicles to our destinations. Mary Slessor Avenue was almost coming to an end as we drove through the following directions, taking left along Calabar Road we have the following site attractions:

The post Office

It was the first and oldest post office in Nigeria, established in (1903) here in Calabar.

De African Club

The club was also established in ( 1903) as a result of the Europeans having their own club, so this was also known the discriminating club for the non Europeans, for Africans, the club drew its members from Coal coast, Sierra Leon, few Yorubas and Efiks. This enables the blacks to have their discussions without the whites knowing.

Another facility is the Watt Market

this is the largest and oldest daily market in Calabar, it was named after a British Merchant known as James Watt,

during the slave era, some slaves were equally sold here, in front is a roundabout with a statue of Late Bassey Duke

he was known as a traditionalist, when he was alive, he paid so much attention to tradition and was equally called the “Ekpe Man” this was because he was a philanthropist; He contributed immensely to the tradition and was equally known as the “lion and the leopard“, each time they have ceremonial occasions in Calabar, the Ekpe Masquerade always pay homage to that statue before they proceed.

The roundabout is always open when the Ekpe Masquerade wants to display.

The next street we entered was Egerton Street and the and the following attractions found there are:

The Statue of late Dr. Lawrence Michael Richard Ekeng Henshaw:

Richard Ekeng Henshaw was the first medical doctor from Calabar, he died in a plane crash in (1955).

The first Pipe Bourne Water: it was established in (1938).

Fernandez Sixtus photo Studio established in (1924).

The Catholic cathedral: this was where the Catholic Bishop stayed.

The next street we drove through after Egerton was Anderson Street, here we found the following:

THE EKIKAK PRINTING PRESS

This printing press was the first printing outfit in Calabar, it also produces wines that most churches uses for their communion on special request and the name of the wine is called “Ekikak Kola”

They also render Hearse Service. The printing press is at No. 1 Anderson Street, Calabar.

We now moved to the European cemetery, what made the cemetery so popular is the Mary Slessor’s tomb, and the visitation of the Queen of England alongside her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, otherwise known as Prince Philip, she laid wreaths in her respect.

Mary Slessor died on (13th January, 1915) , she died in “Use “ in Itu LGA of the present day Akwa Ibom State, her corpse was exhumed and reburied in Old Calabar, The European cemetery.

Thereafter, we moved to Duketown Presbyterian church, it was established in (April, 19, 1904).

The first Christian Wedding took place in this church.

The EKPO EKPO BASSEY’S HOUSE/PREFAB

is also known as a National Monument, the Building was established in (1896), that was where the first mass was observed by Rev. father Lena. The head of the Ekpe is known as Eyamba, there after we moved to the Marina Resort.

MARINA RESORT

It was officially opened on (27th May, 2007) , by the fromer Governor of Cross river State, Mr. Donald Duke.

The Calabar River

the chemistry behind the low and high tide is brackish nature of the river, a mixture of salt and fresh water.

The Calabar River was dredged twice in 2004-2006, and it measuring a depth of 222 fit.

G.B.O Livant is the Dredging Company; it came in the year 1902.

From Marina resort, old resident of slave museum of the facilities witness during the slave trade and some items that served as a medium of exchange are;

ITEM FOR MEDIUM OF EXCHANGE:

Wooden mirror, brass, anklet, cowries, imported trade beads etc.

DANE GUNS: In the 17th century, weapons became an important trade item on the West Africa Coast. This facilitated the use of force in the Rivalry between the foreign traders and trade dispute with local chieves.

NEK SHACKLESS: It was use for capturing slaves.

Slave chain

key for unlocking shackles

iron Shackles: also use for capturing slaves.

KNIFE IN LEADER SHEATH (DANGGOR): Use for defense

BOW: Used for ceremony and defense

SWORD: Used for fighting war

FACILITATORS:

Chief Soriki, Williams Abass (A Slave) boy who turns a slave merchant).

First English slave Voyage (John 1562), in Seria Leon. He got into his possession partly by the sword and partly by other means.

ABOLITIONIST:

LORD Manfield (1705 – 1793).

TIMELINE OF NIGERIAN ART CULTURE FOUND

NOK: Northern Path of Nig-5-6th C

Monolith – Ikom

Calabar

Igbo- Ukwu

Ife: An half figure of an Oni; from Wanm Onije compound (12-15th C)

Owo

Esie

Benin.

BAKOR: The culture presented three hundred (300) carved Colneal stone believed to represent ancestors among the Ekoi people of Cross River State.

MONOLITH: From C.R.S. ” Aban yom or Nkaras people” 16th C

MONOLITH: From c.R.S. Bakor/ Ekoi people 16th C.

ESUK MBA BEACH: In Akpabuyo Local Government Area which is considered to be a point of no reeturn

ESUK MBA SLAVE MARKET: In Akpabuyo L.G.A. where trade by barter still thrives.

HERACULE BAND BICYCLE: It was used by pastor Emmanuel Esin in Oron. The bicycle became the most common means of transport after their advent in the community in the only years of the twentieth century (20th C).

STEERING WHEEL: One of the many government luanches, used for communications mission and the large trading firms had their own vessels.

ANCHOR (AT N.D.83. ORC.67): An iron anchor use for securing the trade canoes of Chief Obokwa Obana of Ikot ana. During his palm oil trading activities on the C.R. between 1920s and the 1950s. Donated by; Mr. Obokwa Obona of Ikot Ana. Akamkpa.
